She's notable for work investigating Russian War Crimes. And also putting away *a lot of people* who abused children, more specifically a lot of child abusers with ties to law enforcement. She resigned her position a few months ago, after Trump's election and subsequent interference in her work. 


Not to suggest this has to have been foul play, before we have any information to support that. But its definitely something to keep an eye on.

Initially suspicious.

Hopefully subsequent news dispels it.

That's just entirely too young for this day and age.
Rest in Peace sad news to hear. I am suspicious about her death. I want investigation for the cause of her death. She was previously investigating Russian money laundering.

Maybe the pilot/flight attendants were concerned he was lying because he was in there for 30+ minutes.

A pilot isn't going to risk their license/job by attacking a passenger and doing damage to the plane. Something had to be going on.

posts.title: The Pentagon's DEI purge: Officials describe a scramble to remove and then restore online content
top_comments:
*While the pages of some well-known veterans... are now back up on Pentagon websites, officials warn that many posts tagged for removal in error may be gone forever.*

Sounds familiar:  they're great at razing but not at raising.
A great use of our tax dollars for sure! /s
What are the odds they will quietly remove them again in a few months, hoping people will be distracted by another thing?

These revisionists deemed the Enola Gay, the Tuskegee airmen, and Major General Charles Rogers's Medal of Honor DEI. They are trying to scrub the history of the military and they call themselves patriots and America First. People really should have paid attention to Project 2025 since now, we have to wait until 2026 to change the Congress.
They also took down the web pages concerning the most decorated military unit in US history, the 442nd Regimental Combat Team. An outcry from veterans restored it.
Racist, homophobic assholes.

Why would people that want to overthrow our democracy spend this much time and effort pissing off the military FOR NO TANGIBLE BENEFIT?

Well I suppose if these people were smart they wouldn’t be racist..
Can’t have anyone thinking women, gays, or the blacks materially participated in our military. /s

I know that they're sworn to obedience, and they are being given lawful orders.

But the orders echo the Nazi purges of the past century. They are actions that mirror the policies of our enemies. The nation mobilized against such things, pouring out blood and treasure to stop them. It was one of our proudest moments, and one that serves to define how we see ourselves as a nation.

The Pentagon shouldn't be "scrambling" to obey such orders, however technically lawful they may be. This purge impresses a stain on the honor of our Armed Forces that will never be expunged. I would expect them to be slow-walking every step. Every order should be met by the impenetrable bureaucracy and red tape that military organizations are famous for. Every signature should be obtained only after each word of the orders and plans are inspected in detail, reviewed by committees, stamped, filed, lost, found, encoded with reference numbers, and distributed to each relevant department. If a form must be filled out, pens should be requisitioned for the purpose. When the pens arrive, they should be deemed unsuitable because the ink viscosity doesn't comply with procurement regulations. The rejected shipment should be returned, and a refund from the contracted vendor obtained and accounted before a new requisition is originated. And once pens are obtained, the forms can be filled out in proper triplicate, to be separated and filed in their widespread destinations. 

Un-American orders need not be expedited; they should be completed with "all deliberate speed". Emphasis on "deliberation". If the "Received" stamp is crooked in its little square, the paperwork should be rejected without explanation until a communication is established to convey that the papers need to be re-done, with a proper cross-reference number linking the rejected paperwork with the replacement.

Removing an entry on a website *ought to take MONTHS.*
It's almost like big balls wrote an algorithm that checks everything against a keyword list of things that this admin wants to erase from history.

top_comments:
> He directed Attorney General Pam Bondi to review the conduct of lawyers and law firms the administration considers to have filed frivolous lawsuits against the Trump administration or attempted to block immigration initiatives, broadening the president’s crackdown on the US legal community in the United States.

[Trump ordered the attorney general to report 'frivolous' lawsuits against his administration so he can consider executive actions against firms. Read the memo.](https://www.businessinsider.com/donald-trump-attorney-general-memo-identify-target-law-firms-2025-3)
If Trump had to go through the actual security clearance process, he would not even be able to get a Secret.

The irony^* of a (then) former president storing classified information in a private bathroom, then becoming president and revoking clearances of other former officials is spectacularly bizarre.

It's not like Clinton is getting a daily intelligence brief.

posts.title: Protesters in Turkey rally 'for justice' after mayor's arrest - BBC News
top_comments: I was in the protests in İzmir yesterday and today, and the police have been illegally throwing pepper spray bombs in the air, using concentrated pepper gas, pepper gas releasing plastic bullets, pressurized water and agent orange with riot control vehicles, and shooting people with plastic bullets, and doing all that without announcing they were going to use excessive force to the public, which is also illegal.

#Tear Gas and Turmoil as Turkey Rises for Justice

The streets of Istanbul have been lit up not by celebration but by the fierce glow of protest as thousands rally for justice following the arrest of the city’s mayor, Ekrem Imamoglu. For four nights running, crowds have surged across Turkey’s major cities, marking the country’s largest wave of demonstrations in over a decade. What began with a few scattered gatherings has now grown into a roar of resistance.

Imamoglu, long seen as a serious rival to President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, was taken into custody on Wednesday, just days before his party was expected to confirm him as their presidential candidate for 2028. Accused of corruption and aiding terrorist groups, charges he flatly denies, his arrest has shaken the political landscape and drawn thousands into the streets demanding his release.

On Saturday, he appeared in court, his supporters chanting "rights, law, justice" outside as tear gas swirled in the cold night air. Riot police stood shoulder to shoulder, firing round after round to break up the crowds, but still they came. Mothers holding their children, students in masks, pensioners waving flags, all united by a shared belief that something fundamental is slipping away.

"I'm here for liberty," one young woman told the BBC, her face hidden behind a mask. "Turkish people cannot accept this. This is against our behaviour and culture." Her words echoed the mood across Istanbul, where the government has banned public gatherings in a bid to quell the unrest. But the ban only seems to have poured fuel on the fire.

In Izmir and Ankara, the story was much the same. Water cannons, arrests, more tear gas. On Friday alone, 343 people were reportedly detained. Still, the crowds held their ground, shouting not in anger but in defiance, determined to be heard. There is an unmistakable feeling that this is no longer just about one man, but about the future of democracy itself in Turkey.

Imamoglu’s bid for the presidency now hangs in the balance. Just a day before his arrest, Istanbul University stripped him of his degree, citing irregularities. If upheld, this would disqualify him from running, as Turkish law requires a university qualification for presidential candidates. The timing has raised eyebrows across the political spectrum.

President Erdogan, who has ruled the country for over two decades, cannot stand again in 2028 unless the constitution is changed. Critics argue that the arrests of Imamoglu and more than a hundred others, including journalists and business figures, are an attempt to clear the political field before the next election. The government, for its part, insists the judiciary is acting independently and has hit out at those suggesting otherwise.

Whether or not that claim holds weight, what is clear is that a growing number of Turkish citizens feel they are being silenced. The sheer courage of those risking arrest to march night after night speaks volumes. These protests are no longer just about one politician behind bars. They are about the soul of a nation, and the kind of future its people are willing to fight for.

Also the plaintiff doesn't specify when it happened, perhaps the plane was close to landing? As everyone knows you can't be in the bathroom during that. Maybe the pilot/flight attendants were concerned he was lying because he was in there for 30+ minutes.

A pilot isn't going to risk their license/job by attacking a passenger and doing damage to the plane. Something had to be going on.
This headline and story seem doubtful

posts.title: The Pentagon's DEI purge: Officials describe a scramble to remove and then restore online content
top_comments:
*While the pages of some well-known veterans... are now back up on Pentagon websites, officials warn that many posts tagged for removal in error may be gone forever.*

Sounds familiar:  they're great at razing but not at raising.
A great use of our tax dollars for sure! /s
What are the odds they will quietly remove them again in a few months, hoping people will be distracted by another thing?

These revisionists deemed the Enola Gay, the Tuskegee airmen, and Major General Charles Rogers's Medal of Honor DEI. They are trying to scrub the history of the military and they call themselves patriots and America First. People really should have paid attention to Project 2025 since now, we have to wait until 2026 to change the Congress.
They also took down the web pages concerning the most decorated military unit in US history, the 442nd Regimental Combat Team. An outcry from veterans restored it.
Racist, homophobic assholes.

Why would people that want to overthrow our democracy spend this much time and effort pissing off the military FOR NO TANGIBLE BENEFIT?

Well I suppose if these people were smart they wouldn’t be racist..
Can’t have anyone thinking women, gays, or the blacks materially participated in our military. /s

I know that they're sworn to obedience, and they are being given lawful orders.

But the orders echo the Nazi purges of the past century. They are actions that mirror the policies of our enemies. The nation mobilized against such things, pouring out blood and treasure to stop them. It was one of our proudest moments, and one that serves to define how we see ourselves as a nation.

The Pentagon shouldn't be "scrambling" to obey such orders, however technically lawful they may be. This purge impresses a stain on the honor of our Armed Forces that will never be expunged. I would expect them to be slow-walking every step. Every order should be met by the impenetrable bureaucracy and red tape that military organizations are famous for. Every signature should be obtained only after each word of the orders and plans are inspected in detail, reviewed by committees, stamped, filed, lost, found, encoded with reference numbers, and distributed to each relevant department. If a form must be filled out, pens should be requisitioned for the purpose. When the pens arrive, they should be deemed unsuitable because the ink viscosity doesn't comply with procurement regulations. The rejected shipment should be returned, and a refund from the contracted vendor obtained and accounted before a new requisition is originated. And once pens are obtained, the forms can be filled out in proper triplicate, to be separated and filed in their widespread destinations. 

Un-American orders need not be expedited; they should be completed with "all deliberate speed". Emphasis on "deliberation". If the "Received" stamp is crooked in its little square, the paperwork should be rejected without explanation until a communication is established to convey that the papers need to be re-done, with a proper cross-reference number linking the rejected paperwork with the replacement.

Removing an entry on a website *ought to take MONTHS.*
It's almost like big balls wrote an algorithm that checks everything against a keyword list of things that this admin wants to erase from history.
